This study investigates the influence of WOx loading on the WOx-modified Pd/Al2O3 catalyst with low Pd content for the catalytic combustion of toluene. Pd/Wx-Al2O3 catalysts with varying WOx loadings were synthesized using the wet impregnation method, based on the monolayer dispersion theory. The monolayer dispersion threshold of WOx on Al2O3 is 0.717 mmol/100 m², which corresponds to a WOx loading of 20 wt%. When the WOx loading is below this threshold, the WOx species on the Al2O3 surface primarily exist as tungstate. Conversely, if the WOx loading exceeds the monolayer dispersion threshold, crystalline WO3 forms. At the monolayer dispersion threshold, the Pd/W20-Al2O3 catalyst exhibits the highest concentration of acidic sites and reactive oxygen species (O₂²⁻ and O₂⁻), demonstrating optimal catalytic activity for toluene combustion. Furthermore, Pd/W20-Al2O3 exhibits excellent long-term stability and resistance to water and sulfur. WOx loadings above or below the monolayer dispersion threshold also influence the reaction pathway of toluene catalytic combustion. Graphical Abstract Keywords Tungsten modified Pd/Al2O3 Toluene Combustion Monolayer dispersion threshold XRD extrapolation Vapor-Sulfur resistance Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction According to the World Health Organization (WHO), volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are organic compounds with a boiling point ranging from 50 to 260 °C at atmospheric pressure [1–4]. VOCs are one of the important precursors to photochemical smog, secondary organic aerosols and tropospheric ozone[5]. The strong toxicity, carcinogenicity, and teratogenicity of VOCs can cause severe harm to human health [6]. With the advancement of industrialization and urbanization, the emission of VOCs is increasing daily, making it essential to mitigate the hazards posed by VOCs pollutants [7]. Catalytic combustion is the most widely used method for eliminating VOCs[3], and the development of efficient catalysts plays a crucial role in the VOCs combustion reaction. These catalysts include noble metal, transition metal oxide [8], rare earth oxide [9], spinel [10] and perovskite [11]. It is generally accepted that noble metals such as Pt and Pd are the most effective catalysts for VOCs combustion [12,13]. Pd/Al2O3 has been extensively utilized in industry. Haneda et al. synthesized Pd/Al2O3 catalysts with different Pd dispersions and found that the activity of the catalyst catalyzing C3H8 combustion reaction decreases as Pd dispersion increases[14]. Zhang et al. prepared mesoporous Al2O3 supported Pt-Pd catalysts (Pt-Pd-Al2O3) via one-step evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) process. The T90 of toluene combustion catalyzed by the catalyst synthesized by EISA method is 60 °C lower than that of the catalyst Pt-Pd/Al2O3 synthesized by the direct impregnation method [15]. However, the high price and limited reserves of noble metals restrict their large-scale application [11]. Therefore, it is crucial to develop catalysts with low noble metals on the premise of ensuring the performance of the catalyst. It has been reported that loading metal oxides on the support can effectively alter the acidity and alkalinity of the catalyst, as well as the valence state and dispersion of the active components, thereby improving its catalytic performance [16]. Zhou et al. employed an ion exchange method to synthesize Ce-modified USY zeolite-loaded Pt catalyst (Pt/Ce-USY) and used to catalyze the combustion of VOCs such as ethylene dichloride, benzene and n-hexane. The increased acidity, redox activity, and higher Pt dispersion of Pt/Ce-USY contribute to the catalyst's superior performance [17]. Taylor et al. synthesized V-modified Pd/Al2O3 using various impregnation sequences. The catalyst (Pd+V)/Al synthesized via the co-impregnation method exhibits the best propane catalytic combustion reaction activity due to its elevated V4 + content [18]. Wang et al. prepared Ba, Zr, La, and Ce modified Pd/Al2O3 catalysts by impregnation method and employed them for the co-oxidation of CO and C3H8. The catalytic activity followed the order of La > Ba > Zr > Ce. La and Ba modification can increase the Pd2+ content, and increase the concentration of weak basic site for the catalyst and promote the dispersion of Pd species [19]. WO3 possesses oxygen vacancies, certain redox activity [20]. Its acidity renders WO3 an important precursor of solid superacid [21]. Numerous studies have reported the application of W-modified noble metal catalysts in hydrocarbon combustion reactions [22–24]. Wu et al. synthesized Pt/WOx/Al2O3 catalysts with varying W loadings through stepwise wet impregnation for propane combustion. The enhancement in the reaction performance was attributed to the interaction between WOx and Pt, leading to the formation of Ptδ+ [22]. Luo et al. modified Pt/BN catalysts using W with different loading amount and compared their catalytic performance in propane combustion. When the W loading amount is 7 wt%, the catalyst (1Pt-7W/BN) exhibits optimal performance, which is attributed to the introduction of new Pt-WO3 active sites by W modification [23]. Guo et al. compared the propane combustion performance of Pt catalysts supported on W-modified tetragonal zirconia (t-ZrO2) and monoclinic zirconia (m-ZrO2). The turnover frequency (TOF) of Pt/WOx/t-ZrO2 at 190 °C is about 2 times higher than that of Pt/WOx/m-ZrO2. The WO3 component is highly dispersed on the surface of t-ZrO2, which enhances the acidity of the catalyst and increases the Pt0 content [24]. Liu et al. modified W single atoms on Pd and loaded them onto Al2O3 surface to obtain the PdW1/Al2O3 catalyst. This catalyst exhibits excellent water resistance in catalyzing methane combustion, due to the electron transfer from W to Pd, which alters the mechanism of methane combustion reaction changes from the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism to a combination of the MvK and Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanisms in the presence of water [25]. In the 1970s, Xie et al. investigated various supported catalysts and discovered that the spontaneous monolayer dispersion phenomenon of oxides or salts on the support surface is quite prevalent, with a specific threshold for the loading amount identified [26]. The theoretical monolayer dispersion threshold can be calculated using the close-packed monolayer model [27]. The monolayer dispersion theory provides a quantitative basis for the loading of supported catalysts, thus holding significant reference value. Our group has conducted extensive systematic research on the monolayer dispersion behavior of active metal oxides on the surface of catalyst support. Shen et al. loaded varying amounts of CuO on the surface of SnO2 and determined that the monolayer dispersion threshold of CuO on SnO2 was 2.09 mmol/100 m2, which corresponding to a Cu loading of 4.8 wt%. When the CuO loading approach the threshold, the catalyst exhibits the highest concentration of surface oxygen site, thereby demonstrating optimal catalytic activity for soot combustion reactions [28]. Liu et al. employed Air-DBD plasma to treat SnO2/Al2O3 catalysts. The monolayer dispersion threshold of the plasma-treated catalyst (0.340 mmol/100 m2) surpassed that of the untreated catalyst (0.262 mmol/100 m2) due to the enhanced acidity and reactant adsorption capacity of plasma-treated catalysts [29]. This theoretical approach has been validated as an effective strategy for designing supported catalysts. Based on the above, the introduction of WOx not only enhances the amount of acidic sites but also increases the amount of reactive oxygen sites. We utilized the monolayer dispersion theory to design and prepare a series of WOx-modified Al2O3 with varying WOx loadings, which were subsequently load with noble metal Pd catalysts (Pd/Wx-Al2O3) for the catalytic combustion of toluene. It was found that the catalyst exhibits optimal toluene combustion activity when the WOx loading reaches the monolayer dispersion threshold. Through a series of characterization methods, the factors influencing the active sites of the catalyst and its reaction activity were thoroughly elucidated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample preparation The Wx-Al2O3 supports were synthesized using the impregnation method. Initially, γ-Al2O3 (99.99 %) was calcined at 600 °C for 4 h to eliminate potential impurities. Subsequently, the γ-Al2O3was dispersed in deionized water, and a 0.05 mol·L−1 solution of (NH4)6[H2(W3O10)4]·xH2O (Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd) was added dropwise. The mixture was stirred overnight and then evaporated to dryness in a water bath at 80 °C, followed by drying in an oven at 110 °C. Finally, after calcination at 550 °C for 4 h, Wx-Al2O3 with varying WO3 loading amounts (where x presents the mass percentage of W element) was obtained. For the supported catalysts, 1.4925 g of Wx-Al2O3 was dispersed in deionized water, followed by the addition of 1.4095 mL of a Pd(NO3)2 solution (Pd(NO3)2·2 H2O, AR, Pd content ≥ 39.5 %) to obtain a concentration of 0.05 mol·L−1 into the beaker. After stirring overnight, the mixture was evaporated to dryness in a water bath at 80 °C, and subsequently dried in an oven at 110 °C. following calcination at 550 °C for 4 h, the target catalysts, denoted as Pd/Wx-Al2O3 (where x presents the mass percentage of W element) were obtained. For comparison, Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/WO3 was synthesized using the same method described above. 2.2 Characterization and catalytic performance evaluation Details regarding the characterization techniques, characterization instrumental information, and performance evaluation methods of the synthesized catalysts are provided in the supplementary materials. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Bulk and surface analysis The crystal structure of modified Wx-Al2O3 supports and the Pd/Wx-Al2O3 catalysts was characterized by XRD. As shown in Fig. S1 (a), these samples exhibit the characteristic diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 when the WOx loading is below 20 %, which align well with the standard cards (Jade 6, PDF#29–0063). As the WOx loading is further increased, the characteristic diffraction peaks of the monoclinic phase WO3 (m-WO3) gradually intensify, which are consistent with the standard card (Jade 6, PDF#20–1323). This monoclinic phase represents the most stable crystal structure of WO3 produced by calcination in air [30]. The monolayer dispersion threshold of WOx on the Al2O3 surface was measured using XRD extrapolation method [27]. Specifically, a linear correlation curve was established between the ratio (IW/IAl) of the peak intensity of the strongest WOx peak (IWO3(020)) divided by the peak intensity of the strongest Al2O3 peak (IAl2O3(440)), plotted against the loading amount of WOx (mmol/100 m2). The loading amounts of WOx were reconfirmed through ICP analysis, aligning with the theoretical values. The specific surface area test results are presented in Table S1. Notably, the specific surface area of the catalysts decreases with increasing WOx loading, attributed to the coverage of the γ-Al2O3 surface by WOx species. As illustrated in Fig. S1 (b), the curve obtained intersects the X-axis at the monolayer dispersion capacity of WO3 on the γ-Al2O3 surface (0.717 mmol/100m2), corresponding to a WOx loading amount of 20 wt%. This value is in close agreement with the theoretical monolayer dispersion threshold (0.816 mmol/100 m²) calculated using the Close-Packed Monolayer model. As presented in Table S1, for the series of 0.5 % Pd loading onto the Wx-Al2O3 catalysts, ICP analysis was conducted to quantify the loading amounts of W and Pd elements. It was found that the WOx loading did not change significantly, while the Pd loading remained approximately 0.5 %. Similarly, the specific surface area did not exhibit a significant variation before and after the Pd loading. Fig. 1(a) and (b) illustrate that the WOx species in the Pd/Wx-Al2O3 catalyst, following the 0.5 wt% Pd loading, predominantly exist in the monoclinic phase of WO3, with no alteration in the monolayer dispersion threshold. The characteristic peak corresponding to Pd species in the XRD pattern is negligible, attributed to the low Pd loading and the high dispersion of Pd on the catalyst surface. Raman spectra were employed to further elucidate the structure of the modified supports and catalysts, with the results presented in Fig. S1 (c) and Fig. 1(c). When the WOx loading below 20 wt%, only the WO stretching vibration peak attributed to monotungstate or polytungstate is observed in the range of 948–972 cm−1 [22,31,32]. As the WOx loading increases, these peaks shift to higher wavenumbers. Wachs and García-Fernández attribute this shift to an increased proportion of polytungstate [33,34], while Stencel et al. found that a decrease in the hydration degree of tungstate can also lead to a shift of the Raman peak to a higher wavenumber [35]. When the WOx loading exceeds 20 wt%, the stretching vibration peak (802 cm−1), bending vibration peak (710 cm−1) and deformation vibration peak (271 cm−1) [20,36–38] of W-O in crystalline WO3 emerge, indicating that crystalline WO3 becomes the predominant WOx species once the loading surpasses the monolayer dispersion threshold. The Raman results further confirm that the monolayer dispersion threshold of WOx on the Al2O3 surface is 0.717 mmol/100m2. For comparison, the Raman spectra of Wx-Al2O3 as the support was also analyzed (Fig. S1 (c)), revealing a variation pattern consistent with that of Pd/Wx-Al2O3. It has been reported that the electronic edge energy (Eg) can reflect the properties of WOx species [21,39,40]. Specifically, when Eg is close to 5.5 eV, it corresponds to WO4²⁻. For values of Eg between 4.0 eV and 5.6 eV, WOx species predominantly exist as monotungstate structures. In the range of 3.7–4.0 eV, WOx species are found in the form of polytungstate structures, while when Eg is less than 3.7 eV, crystalline WO3 begins to form. The UV–vis spectra and UV−vis Kubelka−Munk function results for Pd/Wx-Al2O3 are illustrated in Fig. S2 (a) and (b), no absorption peak is observed in the range of 400–800 nm, indicating that WVI is the only species present on the Al2O3 surface [41]. The average number of covalent W-O-W bonds surrounding the central WVI (NW-O-W) can be calculated using the equation NW-O-W = 11.89–2.37Eg [40]. The value of Eg, NW-O-W and the corresponding WOx species are shown in Fig. 1(d). According to literature reports, when the WOx loading amount is below the monolayer dispersion threshold, WOx species exhibit a monotungstate structure on the Al2O3 surface. At the monolayer dispersion threshold, WOx species exist in a mixed state of monotungstate and polytungstate. When the WOx loading amount exceeds the monolayer dispersion threshold, WOx species coexist as polytungstate and crystalline WO3. For the Pd/WO3 sample, the WOx species are exclusively in the form of crystalline WO3. The Pd dispersion was evaluated through CO adsorption-desorption, as illustrated in Fig. S3 and Table 1, the modification with WOx reduces the dispersion of Pd, likely due to the insufficient Pd anchoring sites on the WO3 surface. However, the WOx modification still facilitates the catalytic combustion of toluene, suggesting that Pd dispersion is not a dominant factor for toluene combustion in this study. Fig. 1(e) presents the H2-TPR profiles of Pd/Wx-Al2O3. The evident is that for all catalysts, an inverted peak appears at 65–70 °C, attributed to the dehydrogenation of PdHx. When the WOx loading below the monolayer dispersion threshold, a weak peak around 600 °C is observed, which attributed to the reduction of tungstate on the surface of Al2O3. In contrast, when the WOx loading exceed the monolayer dispersion threshold, distinct WO3 reduction peaks emerge, corresponding to the reduction process of WO3→WO2.9→WO2.72→WO2 [23,42]. As the WOx loading increases, the reduction peaks shift to lower temperatures, indicating the growth of WO3 crystal grains. We selected the samples Pd/W5-Al2O3, Pd/W20-Al2O3, and Pd/W35-Al2O3, which correspond to before, during, and after the monolayer dispersion threshold, respectively, as typical catalysts. For comparison, Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/WO3 were also examined using TEM, HRTEM, and HAADF-STEM mapping to investigate their morphologies and elemental distributions. As shown in Fig. 2, γ-Al2O3 exhibits a needle-like morphology, while the crystalline WO3 present in Pd/WO3 appears as spherical bulk structures. Notably, no Pd species particles were detected in the HRTEM images for any of the catalysts. The mapping images indicated that Pd species are uniformly dispersed on the catalyst surface for all samples, suggesting a high degree of dispersion due to the low Pd loading. The lattice spacing of the catalyst was measured using Gatan Digital Micrograph software. It was observed that when WOx was dispersed in a monolayer or sub-monolayer state, the diffraction fringes of the WOx species could not be distinguished on the catalyst surface. When the WOx loading approached the threshold, the WOx species exhibited a mist-like distribution on the γ-Al2O3 surface. As the WOx loading exceeded the monolayer dispersion threshold, bulk WO3 crystals began to emerge. The electron microscopy results clearly demonstrate that WOx exhibits a distinct monolayer dispersion threshold effect on the γ-Al2O3 surface. Similarly, we have selected Pd/Al2O3, Pd/W5-Al2O3, Pd/W20-Al2O3, Pd/W35-Al2O3, Pd/W45-Al2O3 and Pd/WO3 as representative catalysts. XPS spectra was further utilized to investigate the surface properties of these catalysts and to validate the conclusions drawn from the XRD extrapolation method. As illustrated in Fig. 3(a), the Pd 3d spectra reveal binding energies located at 336.3–336.8 and 341.7–342.4 eV, which can be attributed to Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2, respectively. Furthermore, the binding energy values suggest that the Pd present on the surface of this series of catalysts predominantly exists in the + 2 state, indicating that it is primarily in the form of PdO. Fig. 3(b) presents the W 4 f spectra of the samples, where the peak positions of all samples are observed near 35.6 eV and 37.7 eV, corresponding to W 4 f7/2 and W 4 f5/2 [43,44], respectively. Based on the binding energy values, it can be concluded that W exists in the W6+ state on the catalyst surface, which is consistent with the UV–vis data. Additionally, as WOx loading increases, the peak intensity of W 4 f also increases. Notably, when the WOx loading exceeds the monolayer dispersion threshold, a Wloss binding energy peak appears at 41.6 eV [45], which can be attributed to the energy loss spectrum of W. Fig. 3(c) illustrates as the WOx loading amount increases, the asymmetry of the O 1 s signal peak also increases, indicating the emergence of multiple oxygen species in various chemical environments. The C1s spectra reveal a binding energy of 288.7 eV, which is attributed to presence of carbonates on the catalyst (Fig. S4 (a)). Consequently, O 1 s spectra can be deconvoluted into four peaks with binding energies at 530.5, 531.8, 533.2 and 531.0 eV, which are respectively assigned to surface lattice oxygen (Olat) [46,47], hydroxyl or carbonate (CO3 2-/OH) [48], peroxide O2 2- and superoxide O2 - [49], respectively. The quantitative results are shown in Table S2. It is well established that O2 - and O2 2- are active oxygen species that facilitate the combustion of toluene; therefore, the (O2 -+O2 2-)/O2- ratio is employed to quantitatively analyze the amount of surface-active oxygen species present in these samples. The (O2 -+O2 2-)/O2- ratios for different samples are shown in Fig. 3(d). It is evident that when the WOx loading amount below 20 wt%, the (O2 -+O2 2-)/O2- ratios increase with rising WOx loading, when the WOx loading amount exceeds 20 wt%, the ratio exhibits a slight decrease. It is noteworthy that as the loading amount of WOx in the support increases, the Pd 3d binding energy values shift towards higher values, while the binding energies of Olat shift from 530.5 eV to 530.28 eV [46], indicating that Pd transfers electrons to oxygen. Fig. S4 (b) shows that the binding energy peak at 74.3 eV corresponds to Al 2p. Notably, the Al 2p binding energy values of these samples do not exhibit significant changes with varying WOx loading. Furthermore, as illustrated in Fig. 3(b), the binding energy values of the W 4 f spectra also remain relatively stable, indicating that electron transfer occurs primarily between Pd and O elements. The results presented here differ from those reported in literatures [23,50], which proved that electron transfer occurs between Pt-W and Pt-Mo, respectively. This discrepancy can be attributed to the differences in synthesis methods. Notably, the catalysts discussed in the aforementioned literatures were synthesized using the co-impregnation method, whereas the catalysts in this study were synthesized through stepwise impregnation. In contrast, literatures [51,52] suggest that the metal-support interaction in catalysts synthesized via the stepwise impregnation method is weaker than that in those produced by the co-impregnation method. The XPS extrapolation method was employed to further investigate the monolayer dispersion threshold of WOx species on the γ-Al2O3 surface for the Pd/Wx-Al2O3 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3(b) and Fig. S4 (b), a series of I W 4 f / I Al 2 p ratios were calculated by dividing the peak intensity of W 4 f7/2 by that of Al 2p. These ratios were then plotted as the ordinate against the loading amount of WOx species on the abscissa. Fig. 3(e) presents two linearly correlated lines with distinct slopes that intersect at a single point, where the corresponding abscissa is 0.72 mmol/100 m2. This finding is consistent with the monolayer dispersion threshold derived from the XRD extrapolation method. The above results indicate that the monolayer dispersion threshold of WO3 on the γ-Al2O3 surface is 0.717 mmol/100 m2, which corresponds to a WOx loading amount of 20 wt%. The loading of Pd has a minor effect on the monolayer dispersion threshold of WO3. When the WOx loading is below this threshold, the predominant form of WOx species is monotungstate. As the WOx loading increases, the polymerization degree of WOx species also increases, transitioning from monotungstate to polytungstate. When the WOx loading exceeds the monolayer dispersion threshold, crystalline WO3 is observed. It was found that Pd transfers electrons to O, with the degree of electron transfer increasing alongside the WOx loading amount. In addition, it can be concluded that when the loading amount of WOx is below the monolayer dispersion threshold, the amount of reactive oxygen species O2 - and O2 2- increase with the increasing of WOx loading. When the loading amount exceeds the threshold, the amount of these corresponding oxygen species gradually decreases. 3.2 Reaction activity evaluation The performance of catalytic combustion of toluene was evaluated under the condition of GHSV= 180, 000 mL·h−1·gcat −1. The catalytic performance of the catalysts is shown in Fig. S5, and the reaction temperatures corresponding to toluene conversions of 10 %, 50 % and 95 % (denoted as T10, T50, T95) are presented in Fig. 4(a). Obviously, Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/WO3 exhibit significantly poor reaction activity. WOx modification effectively enhances the catalytic performance of the catalysts. When the WOx loading is less than 20 wt%, an increase in WOx loading results in a decrease in T50 from 219 °C for Pd/W2-Al2O3 to 206 °C for Pd/W20-Al2O3. However, as the WOx loading continue to increase, the activity of Pd/Wx-Al2O3 in catalyzing toluene combustion begins to decline, indicating the presence of a threshold effect in the catalytic combustion reactions of toluene. By controlling the toluene conversion below 15 % to eliminate the influence of mass and heat transfer, Arrhenius plots were obtained in Fig. 4(b). The reaction rate normalized by catalysts weight (Rw), the turnover frequency (TOF) in 205 °C and the apparent activation energies (Ea) on the catalysts are calculated in Table 1. The above results indicates that Pd/W20-Al2O3 has the lowest activation energy and the highest TOF value. The Ea of Pd/W45-Al2O3 is higher than that of Pd/Al2O3, indicating that the high WOx loading may have a negative effect on catalysts at low temperature. Notably, the Ea of Pd/WO3 is 160 kJ·mol−1, which is much higher than that of Pd/W20-Al2O3 (85 kJ·mol−1), demonstrating that there may be have differences of reaction pathways of toluene combustion between the two catalysts. Based on the test results of toluene combustion performance, it can be concluded that the modification of WOx can effectively enhance the activity of the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst. As shown in Table 2, compared with Pd-based catalysts in the literatures, the Pd/W20-Al2O3 catalyst in this study exhibits good catalytic activity for toluene combustion [53–62]. It could be concluded that when the WOx loading is below the monolayer dispersion threshold, the WOx species exist in an amorphous form of tungstate, leading to a strong metal-support interaction. Conversely, when the WOx loading exceeds this threshold, the emergence of crystalline WO3 diminishes the metal-support interaction, resulting in a decline in catalyst performance. The catalyst Pd/W20-Al2O3, which exhibited optimal reactivity, was employed for a long-term stability test at 210 °C for 50 h. For comparison, the long-term stability of Pd/Al2O3 for catalytic toluene combustion was also evaluated at 235 °C. As illustrated in Fig. 4(c), Pd/W20-Al2O3 displayed a distinct induction period of 3 h, during which the toluene conversion increased from 74 % to 92 %, subsequently maintaining stability for 47 h. In contrast, Pd/Al2O3 demonstrated lower activity relative to Pd/W20-Al2O3, yet it also exhibited a significant induction period during the initial 3 h of the reaction. This indicates that the incorporation of WOx enhances the catalytic combustion activity of toluene and contributes to its stability. The vapor resistance and sulfur resistance of Pd/W20-Al2O3 were also tested, as shown in Fig. 4(d). Initially, after achieving stable toluene conversion, 5 % water vapor was injected into the reaction tube. The toluene conversion decreased from 92 % to 84 % but quickly recovered to its original state. After removing the water vapor for 6 h, 50 ppm of SO2 was introduced into the reaction tube, and the toluene conversion remained unchanged. Following the removal of SO2 and a stabilization period of 6 h, both 50 ppm SO2 and 5 % water vapor were introduced simultaneously, yet the toluene conversion continued to remain stable. In contrast, for Pd/Al2O3, the introduction of 5 % water vapor caused the toluene conversion to drop from 80 % to 72 %, recovering to its original state after the water vapor was removed. When 50 ppm SO2 was introduced, the toluene conversion rapidly declined to 50 %, gradually returning to approximately 74 %. After the removal of SO2, the toluene conversion still recovered to 80 %. When both 5 % water vapor and 50 ppm SO2 were introduced simultaneously, the toluene conversion decreased to 41 %, but it could still recover to its original state after the removal of both components. The toxicity of SO2 on Al2O3 and the competitive adsorption of H2O and toluene negatively affect Pd/Al2O3 [53,63]. These results demonstrate that Pd/W20-Al2O3 not only exhibits good stability but also possesses excellent vapor and sulfur resistance. In other words, WOx modification can enhance the vapor and sulfur resistance of the catalysts. 3.3 Acidic and active oxygen sites analysis Research indicates that the acidic and active oxygen sites of catalysts play a crucial role in the catalytic combustion of toluene [64]. Given that toluene acts as a Lewis base, the acidity of the catalyst directly correlates with its ability to adsorb toluene. The Lewis acid sites of the catalyst interact with the delocalized electrons of the large π bond present in the benzene ring, forming a Lewis acid-base pair that activates the toluene molecule [65]; furthermore, the acidic sites can dissociate and activate the C-H and C-C bonds. Consequently, NH3-TPD and in situ DRIFTS spectra of NH3 adsorption were employed to investigate the strength, amount, and type of acidic sites present in this series of catalysts. The NH3-TPD profiles and quantitative results are shown Fig. S6 (a) and Table S3. The desorption peaks of NH3 are categorized into weak and moderate acidic sites based on temperature ranges: below 230 °C, between 230 °C and 400 °C, respectively [66]. When the WOx loading is below the monolayer dispersion threshold, an increase in WOx loading results in the peak temperatures of weak acidic sites shifting towards higher temperatures, accompanied by an increase in the area desorption peak, indicating an increase in acidity and a corresponding rise in the amount of acidic sites. Conversely, when the loading exceeds the monolayer dispersion threshold, further increases in WOx loading lead to a shift of the peak temperatures of weak acidic sites towards lower temperatures, suggesting a decrease in acidity and a corresponding reduction in the amount of acidic sites. Additionally, the low specific surface area of WO3 contributes to a decreased NH3 desorption amount; as shown in Fig. S6 (a), Pd/WO3 exhibits minimal NH3 adsorption. These results demonstrate that the acidity and amount of acidic sites in this series of catalysts exhibit a significant monolayer dispersion threshold effect. The in situ DRIFTS spectra of NH3 adsorption were employed to further analyze the types of acidic sites present on the surface of these catalysts, as illustrated in Fig. 5(a). The sample was pretreated at 400 °C under a high-purity Ar gas flow for 1 h to eliminate impurities. Subsequently, the temperature was cooled to room temperature, the background was subtracted, and a flow of 1000 ppm NH3/Ar was introduced. Following a 20 min period to achieve adsorption saturation, the relevant IR spectra were recorded. The wavenumbers of 1625 and 1262 cm⁻¹ are attributed to Lewis acidic sites, while the wavenumbers of 1689, 1487, and 1408 cm⁻¹ correspond to Brønsted acidic sites. For Pd/Al2O3, the surface acidic sites of the catalyst are predominantly Lewis acidic sites. When the WOx loading is below the monolayer dispersion threshold, the concentration of Brønsted acidic sites increases with increasing WOx loading; however, when the WOx loading exceeds this threshold, further increases in WOx loading result in a decrease in the concentration of Brønsted acidic sites. In the case of Pd/WO3, the acidic sites are predominantly Lewis acidic sites. These findings indicate that the interaction between Al2O3 and WO3 significantly influences the formation of Brønsted acidic sites. WOx exists on the surface in the form of WO4²⁻ and generates Brønsted acid sites through hydration. When the WOx loading surpasses the monolayer dispersion threshold, the formation of crystalline WO3 leads to a reduction in the concentration of Brønsted acid sites. The adsorption capacity of the catalyst for toluene was further investigated using toluene-TPD. The toluene-TPD profiles and quantitative results are presented in Fig. S6 (b) and Table S4. Peaks observed at temperatures below 140 °C, between 140 °C and 240 °C, and above 240 °C correspond to the desorption of weakly, moderately, and strongly adsorbed toluene, respectively. Notably, the toluene-TPD profiles exhibit a strong resemblance to those of NH3-TPD. When the WOx loading is below the monolayer dispersion threshold, the desorption amounts of weakly adsorbed and moderately adsorbed toluene increase significantly, while the desorption of strongly adsorbed toluene progressively decreases until it is negligible, and their total desorption amounts increase. Conversely, when the WOx loading exceeds the monolayer dispersion threshold, the desorption amounts of weakly adsorbed and moderately adsorbed toluene decline. This phenomenon may be attributed to the increased aggregation of WOx species due to higher WOx loading, which reduces the amount of acidic sites on the catalyst surface. These results indicate that the catalyst exhibits a notable monolayer dispersion threshold effect on toluene adsorption. We depicted a three-dimensional correlation diagram illustrating the relationship between the amount of acidic sites, the desorption amounts from toluene-TPD, and the TOF of the catalysts, as shown in Fig. 5(b). A significant correlation is evident between the amount of acidic sites and the amount of toluene desorption, indicating a clear positive relationship between the acidity of the catalyst and its adsorption capacity for toluene, which aligns with their respective reaction activities, suggesting that the acidic sites of the catalyst and the adsorption capacity of toluene play crucial roles in the toluene combustion. Fig. S7 illustrates the O2-TPD profiles of the Pd/Wx-Al2O3 catalysts, with the quantitative results detailed in Table S5. Previous literature indicates that oxygen desorbing at temperatures below 300 °C is associated with loosely bound oxygen species. Given that the combustion reaction temperature of toluene in this study is below 300 °C, these oxygen species are critical to the reaction. For all the Pd/Wx-Al2O3 catalysts, the oxygen desorption peak shifts to lower temperatures with increasing WOx loading, which suggests a reduction in the binding strength between oxygen and the catalyst surface. This phenomenon may be attributed to the enhanced degree of polymerization of the WOx species. When WOx is dispersed in a monolayer or sub-monolayer, the amount of desorbed oxygen increases with higher WOx loading. However, once the WOx loading surpasses the threshold for monolayer dispersion, the amount of desorbed oxygen decreases. This variation in the amount of desorbed oxygen aligns with the XPS O1s quantitative results of the (O2 -+O2 2-)/O2- ratio, indicating that catalysts with WOx loadings near this threshold exhibit the strongest oxygen adsorption-desorption capability. Correlation plots between the quantitative results of the (O2 -+O2 2-)/O2- ratio, the O2-TPD results, and the TOF of these catalysts are presented in Fig. 5(c). The TOF, (O2 -+O2 2-)/O2- ratio, and the amount of oxygen desorption in the O2-TPD of the catalyst for the toluene combustion reaction demonstrate a significant positive correlation, underscoring the crucial role of active oxygen sites in the toluene combustion reaction. 3.4 In situ DRIFTS spectra analysis In situ DRIFTS was employed to characterize the intermediates involved in catalytic toluene combustion. The assignments of the IR bands corresponding to the absorbed species are presented in Table 3. The catalyst underwent pretreatment with argon at 400 °C for 1 h to eliminate impurities, after which 1000 ppm toluene in air was introduced into the in situ cell. The potential intermediates of catalytic toluene combustion were examined at varying temperatures, as illustrated in Fig. 6(a)-(e). Based on literature reports, the combustion reaction of toluene may proceed via two distinct pathways [67,68]: In pathway A, the benzyl group of toluene is sequentially oxidized to benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde, benzoic acid, and subsequently further oxidized to phenol, p-benzoquinone, and maleic anhydride, ultimately leading to ring-opening to form CO2 and H2O. In pathway B, the oxidation process of the benzyl group is analogous to that in pathway A, i.e., toluene → benzyl alcohol → benzaldehyde → benzoic acid; however, the ring-opening process diverges, as benzoic acid is directly oxidized to CO2 and H2O. These two reaction pathways are depicted in Scheme 1. Fig. 6(a) illustrates that for the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst, the IR bands at 2970, 2937, and 2882 cm⁻¹ correspond to the C-H stretching vibrations of the CH3 group in toluene, which gradually diminish with increasing temperature. The C-H stretching vibration peak at 3070 cm⁻¹ , associated with the benzene ring, remains present even at a reaction temperature of 290 °C. As the reaction temperature increases, the C-C stretching vibration peaks at 1498 and 1604 cm⁻¹ , which represent the carbon skeleton of the benzene ring, significantly weaken. Concurrently, the peak intensities of benzene quinone (1670 cm⁻¹) and maleic anhydride (1967–1740 cm⁻¹) increase, indicating that the reaction adheres to Pathway A. As shown in Fig. 6(b)-(c), the WOx modification significantly enhances toluene conversion, as evidenced by the decreasing and eventual disappearance of the stretching vibration peaks of the benzyl group and the C-H bonds on the benzene ring with increasing reaction temperature. Furthermore, compared to the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst, the modified catalyst exhibits increased concentrations of oxygen-containing intermediates such as benzoic acid (1578, 1540, 1455, 1420 cm⁻¹) and benzaldehyde (1650 cm⁻¹) during the toluene combustion reaction, indicating that WOx modification accelerates the oxidation of the benzyl group. When the dispersion state of WOx species is monolayer or sub-monolayer, a higher WOx loading results in a stronger promoting effect on the oxidation of the methyl group in toluene, thereby facilitating the progress of the reaction. As illustrated in Fig. S8 (b), the Pd/W35-Al2O3 catalyst demonstrates a robust capability to activate toluene into benzaldehyde and benzoic acid. However, in comparison to the catalyst prior to reaching the threshold, the peak intensity at 1670 cm−1, corresponding to benzene quinone, and the peak intensity within the range of 1967–1740 cm−1, associated with maleic anhydride, have markedly diminished. This reduction indicates that the ring-opening process of benzoic acid converting into benzene quinone and subsequently into maleic anhydride is constrained, suggesting that the reaction predominantly follows Pathway B. It is widely accepted that the ring-opening of the benzene ring is the rate-determining step in the catalytic combustion of toluene reaction [69]; thus, the pathway of this process significantly influences the reaction rate. As depicted in Fig. 6(d), with an additional increase in WOx loading, the concentrations of benzene quinone and maleic anhydride further decline. Furthermore, an adsorption peak attributed to CO is observed at 2060 cm−1, indicating that when the WOx loading exceeds the monolayer dispersion threshold, CO may also serve as a possible intermediate product. CO may compete with toluene and O2 for adsorption on the catalyst surface, which might result in a decrease in the activity of catalyst. As shown in Fig. 6(e), the low specific surface area of WO3 and the absence of acidic sites for toluene adsorption hinder the detection of adsorbed toluene species on the Pd/WO3 surface, resulting in the observation of only trace amounts of intermediates such as benzaldehyde and maleic anhydride. The weak adsorption of toluene leads to poor catalytic activity. Considering that the Pd/W20-Al2O3 catalyst exhibits the highest catalytic activity for the toluene combustion reaction in this study, the intermediates of the toluene combustion reaction at 230 °C were investigated as follows: First, the catalyst was pretreated at 400 °C under an Ar atmosphere for 1 h, then cooled to 230 °C, and a 1000 ppm toluene/Ar mixture was introduced. As displayed in Fig. 6(f), it was observed that the C-H stretching vibration bands of the benzyl group appeared at 2930 and 2873 cm⁻¹ , while the C-C skeletal vibration band of the benzene ring appeared at 1604 cm⁻¹ . Only a small amount of benzaldehyde and benzoic acid intermediates could be detected, indicating that the catalyst has a weaker activation ability for toluene in the absence of O2. After 30 min, the catalyst reached toluene adsorption saturation. The 1000 ppm toluene/Ar mixture was then removed, and air was introduced. It was observed that the C-H vibration bands of the benzyl group gradually disappeared, while the peaks at 1730, 1781, and 1858 cm⁻¹ , attributed to maleic anhydride, and the peak at 1670 cm⁻¹ , attributed to benzene quinone, gradually increased in intensity, indicating that the reaction predominantly proceeds along Pathway A. In summary, in situ DRIFTS indicates that when WOx species are present in monolayer or sub-monolayer dispersion, the catalyst enhances the toluene combustion reaction via pathway A. Furthermore, WOx modification promotes the oxidation of toluene, thereby accelerating the reaction. However, when the WOx loading surpasses the monolayer dispersion threshold, the ring-opening reaction of benzoic acid becomes constrained, leading the reaction to proceed via pathway B. 3.5 Toluene-TPSR-MS analysis To further investigate the possible reaction pathways, toluene -TPSR-MS tests were conducted on the catalyst, and the mass spectrum signals were differentiated to obtain their differential curves. The peak of the differential curve indicates the temperature at which the catalyst achieves its maximum reaction rate. Initially, the sample was purged with high-purity Ar at 400 °C to remove surface impurities from the catalyst. Subsequently, it was cooled to room temperature, and toluene was introduced into the reaction tube using 10 % O2/Ar gas mixture. The temperature was then increased at a rate of 10 °C/min to 350 °C, and the mass signal of the exhaust gas was detected. As shown in Fig. 7(a)-(c), for all catalysts, the peak temperature for CO2 production is lower than that for O2 consumption. This discrepancy is attributed to the presence of multiple oxygen-consuming processes in the toluene combustion reaction pathway, whereas CO2 production solely involves the pathways A and B, as illustrated in Scheme 1. Consequently, the production of CO2 lags behind the consumption of O2. Among the catalysts, the temperature difference (ΔT) between the peak reaction rate temperatures for CO2 production and O2 consumption is 29 °C, 2 °C, and 38 °C for Pd/W5-Al2O3, Pd/W20-Al2O3, and Pd/W45-Al2O3, respectively. The Pd/W20-Al2O3 catalyst exhibits high catalytic activity for both the benzylic oxidation of toluene and the ring-opening reaction of benzoic acid to produce CO2, facilitating the rapid conversion of toluene into CO2, which results in a smaller temperature difference between the peak CO2 production and peak O2 consumption. In situ DRIFTS results reveal that the dispersion state of WOx significantly influences the reaction pathway of toluene catalyzed by the Pd/Wx-Al2O3. When the WOx loading is below the threshold, the combustion reaction of toluene follows the pathway: toluene → benzyl alcohol → benzaldehyde → benzoic acid → phenol → benzoquinone → maleic anhydride → CO2 + H2O. In cases where WOx species exists in a monolayer or sub-monolayer state, increasing the WOx loading enhances both the acidity and reactive oxygen amount of the catalyst, thereby making the benzyl group of toluene more prone to oxidation, resulting in intermediates such as benzaldehyde and benzoic acid, which in turn increases reaction activity. However, when the WOx loading surpasses the monolayer dispersion threshold, crystalline WO3 forms, which restricts pathway A, where benzoic acid is further oxidized to phenol and benzoquinone, shifting the reaction towards pathway B (benzoic acid → H2O and CO2). Toluene -TPSR-MS experiments further demonstrate that Pd/W20-Al2O3 exhibits a faster rate of toluene oxidation. 4 Conclusion To investigate the influence of the monolayer dispersion behavior of WOx on Pd/Wx-Al2O3 catalysts, a series of Pd/Wx-Al2O3 catalysts with varying WOx loadings were synthesized using the wet impregnation method. The catalysts were characterized through various techniques, and their reactivity in the catalytic combustion of toluene was evaluated. The conclusions are as follows: 1) The results obtained from XRD, Raman spectroscopy, UV–vis, XPS, TEM, and EDX-mapping indicate that the monolayer dispersion threshold of WOx species on the Al2O3 surface is 0.717 mmol/100 m², corresponding to a WOx loading of 20 %. The loading of Pd does not significantly impact the monolayer dispersion threshold. When the WOx loading is below this threshold, the WOx species predominantly exist as tungstate. Conversely, when the WOx loading exceeds the monolayer dispersion threshold, crystalline WO3 is observed. XPS analysis reveals electron transfer from Pd to O. The catalyst exhibits the highest (O2 -+O2 2-)/O2- ratio when the WOx loading is at the monolayer dispersion threshold. 2) NH3-TPD and toluene-TPD indicate that both the acidity and toluene adsorption capacity of the catalyst demonstrate a significant monolayer dispersion threshold effect. Furthermore, a clear correlation exists between the acidity and toluene adsorption capacity of the catalysts, which correlates well with the reactivity in toluene combustion. O2-TPD reveals that the reactive oxygen sites of the catalyst also exhibit a notable monolayer dispersion threshold effect, showing a distinct correlation with the combustion performance of toluene. These results suggest that acidity, toluene adsorption capacity, and active oxygen sites are critical factors influencing the reactivity of toluene combustion. 3) In situ DIRFTS experiments indicate that the monolayer dispersion threshold effect of WOx can significantly influence the pathway of the toluene combustion reaction. When the WOx loading is below the monolayer dispersion threshold, the ring-opening process of toluene follows the sequence: benzoic acid → phenol → benzoquinone → maleic anhydride → CO2 + H2O. Conversely, when the WOx loading exceeds the monolayer dispersion threshold, the ring-opening process tends to simplify to: benzoic acid → CO2 + H2O. In summary, at the monolayer dispersion threshold, the Pd/W20-Al2O3 catalyst exhibits the strongest acidity, the highest toluene adsorption capacity, and the richest active oxygen species. This catalyst also demonstrates optimal catalytic activity for toluene combustion, along with excellent resistance to water and sulfur. These results indicate that the monolayer dispersion theory provides a quantitative basis for the loading of supported catalysts and holds significant reference value. coredata.dc:description: This study investigates the influence of WOx loading on the WOx-modified Pd/Al2O3 catalyst with low Pd content for the catalytic combustion of toluene. Pd/Wx-Al2O3 catalysts with varying WOx loadings were synthesized using the wet impregnation method, based on the monolayer dispersion theory. The monolayer dispersion threshold of WOx on Al2O3 is 0.717 mmol/100 m², which corresponds to a WOx loading of 20 wt%. When the WOx loading is below this threshold, the WOx species on the Al2O3 surface primarily exist as tungstate. Conversely, if the WOx loading exceeds the monolayer dispersion threshold, crystalline WO3 forms. At the monolayer dispersion threshold, the Pd/W20-Al2O3 catalyst exhibits the highest concentration of acidic sites and reactive oxygen species (O₂²⁻ and O₂⁻), demonstrating optimal catalytic activity for toluene combustion. Furthermore, Pd/W20-Al2O3 exhibits excellent long-term stability and resistance to water and sulfur. WOx loadings above or below the monolayer dispersion threshold also influence the reaction pathway of toluene catalytic combustion.
